post.title: Giving women the right to vote was a mistake

body:
I’m not sure where I stand on this. On one hand I am a very strong proponent 
 of equality, and having observed literally hundreds maybe even thousands of women in the top academic fields in the country I truly believe they are in some senses objectively smarter than men (now that’s a *real* unpopular opinion); **however** they often times are easily swayed, indecisive, emotional, and don’t actually know what they want; a trait that can be extremely dangerous when making life or death decisions, as well as public policy which affects hundreds of millions of people. 

I think ultimately the risks of disenfranchising half the population outweigh the overall benefit of avoiding the female penchant for  irrational lines of thinking (and voting); because no matter how good the policy, I don’t want to live somewhere that can tell me I can’t vote because of the way I was born, and it’s ideologically hypocritical to impose an alternative standard on another human being.

Ok so yeah I disagree; I’m a supporter of women voting.

Ok so yeah I disagree; I’m a supporter of women voting.

post.title: Giving women the right to vote was a mistake

body:
I think men and women are inherently different and women want to be taken care of moreso than men.

And to be taken care of a woman had to pair up with a man who would provide that to her. Since women got the vote we have seen an ever growing list of entitlements from the government that allow it to provide instead. But the government isn't a person, it doesn't look you in the eye at dinner and make you feel guilty for taking advantage of it.

I've personally known a woman, with children, and a "husband" whom they live with and share responsibility for the kids and bills, which is what we want to see. But I put husband in quotes because they had no legal marriage, just a muslim ceremony, so as far as any of their peers are concerned they are married. But they avoided the legal marriage because they lie about who lives in the house, and get welfare at an increased amount because she is technically a 'single parent.'

This is obviously an anecdote. But me being someone who thinks you should get nothing but national protection and law enforcement from your government, I find it despicable. And I don't know that it wouldn't exist if women didn't vote. But I have my suspicions.

Consider for example the period of time between creation and the flood: at first, literally everyone was good, then shortly after, only 3/4 of people could be considered "good," then fast forward to just before the flood and basically everyone was utterly wicked except for noah and his family.

Likewise then immediately after the flood, most people were "good," then over time things got worse again, until Jesus came and shined his light upon the world, and things got a little better, there were many "good" people, and over time it got worse again.

body:
> at first, literally everyone was good, then shortly after, only 3/4 of people could be considered "good," then fast forward to just before the flood and basically everyone was utterly wicked except for noah and his family.

At first, "everyone" was Adam and Eve and their family. Humanity hasn't been anywhere near as corrupt as before the flood ever since then, aside from a few specific instances. When's the last time a civilization was destroyed for that?

> Likewise then immediately after the flood, most people were "good," then over time things got worse again

Again, because "everyone" here is Noah and his family.

> there were many "good" people, and over time it got worse again.

I don't see how it's gotten worse. Outside of a few third-world countries, when is the last time people were burned alive on the streets and thrown in arenas to be ripped to shreds by wild animals, enjoyed by a sadistic audience of everyday people? Do people still have slaves that they rape and kill regularly (and even women and children)? This is how the most "civilized" people used to act, not just a few antifa looters here and there. Times are certainly not perfect now, but I don't know how you could think that they were better before.

> to include greece, rome, and now the US, among others.

Greece and Rome were strongest when they deluded themselves and had no morals. When Christianity spread in Rome, morality increased and prevented them from doing many of the immoral things necessary to maintain such an empire. In fact, aside from having to be brutal, such faith in the "greatness" of their empires is pride and idolatry. Don't look back at Rome and Greece and think they had some kind of great morality, that's just nostalgia.

Please bear in mind, tradition ≠ morality.

> but can you really make the claim that people aren't becoming more and more wicked? Ive heard personal testimony from more than a few people talking about when they could leave their door unlocked and let their kids play out in the street who would no longer feel comfortable doing that today.

Yes, people don't keep slaves and kids that they make do all their work and assault them for pleasure, people don't get turned into candles or ripped apart by wild animals for not worshipping the emperor, most people are actually willing to do *some* negotiating and have a better idea of justice than "You did something bad to me so I'm killing your whole family slowly and painfully and burning your house down and looting all you have and raping and assaulting you and chopping your body parts off one by one until you die!". Today, we have that kind of thing in, say, North Korea. That used to be almost everything. People are still like their ancestors at heart but they are at least willing to keep some control over it now. And about parents not feeling comfortable letting their kids outside anymore, media. Nowadays we hear about every story all over the news, and on top of that our recent culture has been *way* too nanny-like, worrying about every tiny thing that could possibly happen and thinking we have to do everything we can to make sure everything is perfect and nothing ever happens. It's not because the world is actually so dangerous now, and if it were it's because there's a lot more people in it, not because they're worse in general.

> As far as woman voting, they are merely a tool for Satan to more effectively control who is elected, given that woman are more easily manipulated/deceived.

*All* people are like this, which is why I don't trust people in general. Changing which demographics can vote isn't going to solve this problem, it just silences them. That's worse, because even people with good intentions cannot understand the lives of people besides themselves, and don't always make the right judgements. "Some/average people are too foolish" is the same argument used by monarchs to justify their "divine right" to rule over people. They're 100% correct about people being foolish, but miss that they themselves are usually even worse. It's hypocritical, and it's why I agree with Thomas Hobbes's premise but have no idea how that led him to his conclusion. People are evil, so how can you trust them to control things?

In fact, aside from having to be brutal, such faith in the "greatness" of their empires is pride and idolatry. Don't look back at Rome and Greece and think they had some kind of great morality, that's just nostalgia.

Please bear in mind, tradition ≠ morality.

but can you really make the claim that people aren't becoming more and more wicked? Ive heard personal testimony from more than a few people talking about when they could leave their door unlocked and let their kids play out in the street who would no longer feel comfortable doing that today.

Yes, people don't keep slaves and kids that they make do all their work and assault them for pleasure, people don't get turned into candles or ripped apart by wild animals for not worshipping the emperor, most people are actually willing to do some negotiating and have a better idea of justice than "You did something bad to me so I'm killing your whole family slowly and painfully and burning your house down and looting all you have and raping and assaulting you and chopping your body parts off one by one until you die!". Today, we have that kind of thing in, say, North Korea. That used to be almost everything. People are still like their ancestors at heart but they are at least willing to keep some control over it now. And about parents not feeling comfortable letting their kids outside anymore, media. Nowadays we hear about every story all over the news, and on top of that our recent culture has been way too nanny-like, worrying about every tiny thing that could possibly happen and thinking we have to do everything we can to make sure everything is perfect and nothing ever happens. It's not because the world is actually so dangerous now, and if it were it's because there's a lot more people in it, not because they're worse in general.

As far as woman voting, they are merely a tool for Satan to more effectively control who is elected, given that woman are more easily manipulated/deceived.

All people are like this, which is why I don't trust people in general. Changing which demographics can vote isn't going to solve this problem, it just silences them. That's worse, because even people with good intentions cannot understand the lives of people besides themselves, and don't always make the right judgements. "Some/average people are too foolish" is the same argument used by monarchs to justify their "divine right" to rule over people. They're 100% correct about people being foolish, but miss that they themselves are usually even worse. It's hypocritical, and it's why I agree with Thomas Hobbes's premise but have no idea how that led him to his conclusion. People are evil, so how can you trust them to control things?

body:
It goes through cycles, or waves if you will, does it not?  We may be living in a time or relative peace, and yet be facing a time of extreme persecution.  I would say the true body of Christ is facing pretty severe persecution, but we don't see it because its not given the same sort of attention as Trump having the flu.  Whether it is done openly would have a difference on your perception, would it not?  And worldly history books are curated by Satan, no? Much of what has happened in the way of persecution is hidden in mainstream history, im not sure how much youve studied it (i dont claim to be an expert) but the picture i builds suggests a sort of cyclical but still ever increasing persecution.

You can choose to interpret Matthew 24, but there are other references to wicked increasing over time in the scripture, to include what we can only assume happened between the time of creation and the flood.

I agree that there have been times of severe barbarism to include what you talked about in Rome with galdiator fights and what not, but if i understand correctly that was toward the point of fullness of wickedness, or at least thats my understanding of it. In other words, you may be able to watch the same thing on TV in 10 years from now.  Consider the progression from boxing to ufc for example, and people's demands and cries for blood are ever increasing.  The murder mystery section of libraries has no shortage of choices. Pedophilia and incest is being openly advocated for and the boundries are being pushed further and further every year.

parent.body: Yes, and I can see where you're going with the "increase in wickedness" part. But that's referring to the *very* end, when the great persecutions occur again (but even worse) and the antichrist arrives. That hasn't happened just yet, and for now we're living in a period of relative peace compared to most of history. Even just a few centuries ago, you'd be facing the threat of torture and execution if you dared proclaim the truth. Now all you need to worry about is some strangers making rude remarks (unless you try to talk at an Antifa rally or something, but that's the exception, not the institutionalized norm).

post.title: Giving women the right to vote was a mistake

body:
Nah, this isn't +defendyourposition 

It is an unpopular opinion and I wanted to stir the pot and see what everyone says on the issue. It worked really well considering there are 40+ comments and the post is only at 8 points. There are some salty people in this thread. Clearly it is a volatile subject and very unpopular, so mission accomplished. I don't necessarily think women shouldn't be allowed to vote, I actually have a larger disagreement with our methods, but this is usually a good way to get people arguing about it.

I think voting should only be given to family units instead of individuals because voting is about the future, not the present. Each household should get one vote, and you should only get a vote when you own property AND have children. The property thing needs to be a low bar, but it needs to be there imo. 

Also, and perhaps most importantly, childless people should NOT be allowed to hold public office. Married and childless? Fuck off, no voting and no holding office. Single but with kids? Sure you can vote, but if you receive federal assistance AT ALL, then you lose your right to vote. You must become self sufficient in order to vote again because you have a conflict of interest in voting since you are financially incentivized to vote a certain way due to your circumstances. Unmarried and childless? Enjoy being a child yourself while the rest of us make adult decisions about the future.

Voting should NOT be given to everyone. You and your spouse should have to pass a test to earn the privilege to vote after you qualify. And if you skip voting one year, your family should lose your privileges until you or your spouse take a standardized test to prove your knowledge about how our country runs. Something like what immigrants take on moving here that could be passed by a high school student.

post.title: Giving women the right to vote was a mistake

body:
I'm actually not against women voting, I'm against the way our system works in general. I think each family should be given one vote instead of every adult, and you can only vote after passing a test similar to what immigrants pass. Also, if you are on ANY subsidies or government assistance, no voting. If you are childless, no voting AND no holding public office. Your family skipped voting one year? Guess what, enjoy taking the test again to earn that privilege back. You are a dual citizen? Cool, no voting and no holding office. Your loyalties are in question, so you should not have a say in how this country is run.

Voting and holding office are about the future and making things better IN THIS COUNTRY. Not having children and not being a property owner makes you less vested in the country and our future success. Also, there should still be some sort of property requirement as well, but it should be fairly minimal and easy to obtain after a few years of work. 

Voting should NOT be a right. It should be a privilege. 

This was just a fun way to stir the pot. And it worked.

parent.body:
I’m not sure where I stand on this. On one hand I am a very strong proponent 
 of equality, and having observed literally hundreds maybe even thousands of women in the top academic fields in the country I truly believe they are in some senses objectively smarter than men (now that’s a *real* unpopular opinion); **however** they often times are easily swayed, indecisive, emotional, and don’t actually know what they want; a trait that can be extremely dangerous when making life or death decisions, as well as public policy which affects hundreds of millions of people. 

I think ultimately the risks of disenfranchising half the population outweigh the overall benefit of avoiding the female penchant for  irrational lines of thinking (and voting); because no matter how good the policy, I don’t want to live somewhere that can tell me I can’t vote because of the way I was born, and it’s ideologically hypocritical to impose an alternative standard on another human being.

Ok so yeah I disagree; I’m a supporter of women voting.

There are plenty of third world countries where similar barbarism happens today, but keep in mind that this was characteristic of the *most civilized* nations back in the day; the others were even *worse*. It's easy to get nostalgic and romanticize those time periods, but in reality they weren't so great.

body: Based on your what you've said, it sounds like you're assuming we're the last generation in existence and that the final 7 years is just around the corner. While I cannot confirm or deny that, every generation in history has thought the same thing and I try to be more careful about jumping to those kinds of conclusions. Everything always looks worse from your own perspective, so it's easy to look at all the awful things in life today and think "it couldn't be worse!". I do agree that this is the general end times, as has been the case for ~2000 years, but I don't think we're at the *very* end currently.

We may not be tossed into lions den's, but we are tossed into public schools, and last i checked the lion can only kill the body, but the public schools kill the soul, do they not?  Is it not the schools that suck the life out of children? That lead them down the paths of destruction? Is it not the jobs we then move to, which while offering the best benefit packages, continue draining a person of what little happiness and hope remains after leaving school?

Is it not the owners of these mega corporations, who while bathing in gold, and imagining how they can get more, come to the conclusion that they will give less, thus achieving their dream of obtaining the plane or castle which will *finally* give them the satisfaction and contentment they've been seeking for so long? or is it not the plane and castle they truly desire, but rather the awareness that to obtain such things, they must force others into lives of prolonged suffering, the plane and castle merely being tokens of the suffering they've accomplished to force onto the lives of countless others?

What's worse, criminals being fed to lions for the public to satisfy their thirst for death, or billions of people living in conditions of squalor and malnutrition, day after day, with no hope of ever escaping? What's worse, being behind physicals bars in a prison, or being behind spiritual bars in your mind? What's worse: being trapped in a physical dungeon, laying on a cold floor, receiving minimal food, or being trapped in a mental dungeon, receiving no spiritual nourishment, and feeling the coldest of antarctic colds permeating the inner most parts of your soul?

body:
> And until then, things will wax worse and worse.

That's what we disagree on then. I don't believe everything necessarily follows a linear progression. It can go in waves and cycles, the only thing we know is that it will be the worst at the very end. What the world will be like right before then I can't predict, but an increase in evil is one of the major "very end" signs and it sounds like it will happen rapidly.

The other examples you've listed are not specific to this time in history, and unfortunately are the reality of life in this world. They are serious problems that need attention, but few of them are new. It has no relation to the time period. Schools, draining jobs, greed, selfishness, poverty, mental/spiritual issues, etc. and other variations of those things were just as rampant in the past as they are now. There was a short time in the early US where the first two were mostly absent, but that is abnormal.

body:
Yeah okay well i did my best. The bible says what it says, you say what you say, and i choose to believe the bible instead, especially because what the bible (Jesus) says more accurately reflects the world that ive witnessed in my 30 years of living. 

Not sure where you're at in life, but to pretend that a country immersed in sexual perversions which are glorified on TV, the sorts of perversions where parents sexualize their own children for filthy lucre's sake...to pretend that we are somehow more moral now than we were in times past, sounds like blissful ignorance.

The line is cyclical in nature, with a trend towards evil.  Which is to say that the world can and will never be as moral as it was at the beginning; and conversely, that the world can not be nor has never been as immoral as it will be at the end.

body:
You are saying what you say just as much as I am. The only comment the Bible makes on this is the sharp increase of evil at the very end, which has not arrived yet.

> Not sure where you're at in life, but to pretend that a country immersed in sexual perversions which are glorified on TV, the sorts of perversions where parents sexualize their own children for filthy lucre's sake...to pretend that we are somehow more moral now than we were in times past, sounds like blissful ignorance.

Because this was far worse in the past. In most civilizations throughout history, children and slaves were treated as property at their owner's disposal, and society saw absolutely nothing wrong with literally assaulting them and raping them for your own pleasure. Often times, acts against lower classes was perfectly fine as well. Keep in mind that this was *nearly everyone*, not just a few extremists like it is nowadays and such acts are not tolerated. In Roman times, one of the biggest debates was whether *literally burning infants and children alive as sacrifices* was an acceptable practice. In the Renaissance, Pharisaic behavior was rampant. The things we see today are very much toned down from what they usually are. There are ages in history of more evil, and ages of less evil (note: still a lot), but based on history I can't agree that now is the worst. I used to assume it was too, but that was before I learned what people were really like in the past. However

> The line is cyclical in nature, with a trend towards evil. Which is to say that the world can and will never be as moral as it was at the beginning; and conversely, that the world can not be nor has never been as immoral as it will be at the end.

The trend is always towards evil. You seem to think I'm saying people are inherently better nowadays, which I'm not. People have always been the same level of evil (human nature), it's just a matter of how much they try to *look* good. And modern times in general have done that more than ancient ones. At the beginning there were literally two people in the world, so that's hard to compare to; and almost immediately after that things became very bad. This was also the case after the flood. That's not a picture of everyone is good at the beginning, aside from the initial few. The only thing we know is that the final 7 years will be the worst, not that the beginning was better than normal.

body:
I'm not in line with what the world says. The world says it is good, which I certainly don't believe. I'm actually refuting that people were generally "good" in the past. The world also looks up to past pagan civilizations and their "legacy".

> You're welcome to interpret Matthew 24 how you would like, but ill choose to interpret it plainly, as it reads.

It plainly speaks of an increase of evil at the very end, and that persecution will be increased during that time. It makes no comment on before that:

> "And you will hear of wars and rumors of wars. *See that you are not alarmed, for this must take place, but the end is not yet*. For nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom, and there will be famines [and plagues] and earthquakes in various places. All these are but the beginning of the birth pains. *Then they will deliver you up to tribulation and put you to death, and you will be hated by all nations for my name’s sake*. And then many will fall away and betray one another and hate one another. And many false prophets will arise and lead many astray. *And because lawlessness will be increased, the love of many will grow cold*. But the one who endures to the end [, they] will be saved. And this gospel of the kingdom will be proclaimed throughout the whole world as a testimony to all nations, and then the end will come."

(ESV), brackets []=Only contained in some manuscripts

body:
> Humanity tends toward evil. Things started good, then got worse over time, just as nations often start good, and get progressively worse over time.

I agree entirely with that statement, except that it started good. It went bad the second the tree of knowledge was eaten from, and there has been different levels of trying to hide it but I don't think this has changed since then.

> How can you say we are not progressing toward a more evil condition as a nation when was what once shunned (fornication) is now glorified? Likewise violence, deceit, blasphemy, and all things whatsoever are evil? I agree that the US wasn't ever morally perfect, but going back in time 100 years, it sure seems like people behaved much more in line with what God commanded.

I'm not just talking about 100 years ago, and I somewhat agree with you about that. But compared to the vast majority of human history, both times are far better than average. Also note that even the earlier US had its own problems which may be different from ours, for example you'd see more wrath, racism, stiff-neckedness, and in many cases more violence too. And do take into account that a lot of times when "most people were Christian" was just an outside-of-the-cup act for people to exalt themselves, like the Pharisees did, and it wasn't truly different from now at heart.

> Left to our own devices we will always progress to a more morally degraded condition

Again, you're assuming that people were ever inherently good.

> and sure you wouldnt argue that this nation has become more Christlike as of late, would you?

Of course not, I've clarified this multiple times. It's not that the present is good, just that the past wasn't always better.

parent.body:
Nah, this isn't +defendyourposition 

It is an unpopular opinion and I wanted to stir the pot and see what everyone says on the issue. It worked really well considering there are 40+ comments and the post is only at 8 points. There are some salty people in this thread. Clearly it is a volatile subject and very unpopular, so mission accomplished. I don't necessarily think women shouldn't be allowed to vote, I actually have a larger disagreement with our methods, but this is usually a good way to get people arguing about it.

I think voting should only be given to family units instead of individuals because voting is about the future, not the present. Each household should get one vote, and you should only get a vote when you own property AND have children. The property thing needs to be a low bar, but it needs to be there imo. 

Also, and perhaps most importantly, childless people should NOT be allowed to hold public office. Married and childless? Fuck off, no voting and no holding office. Single but with kids? Sure you can vote, but if you receive federal assistance AT ALL, then you lose your right to vote. You must become self sufficient in order to vote again because you have a conflict of interest in voting since you are financially incentivized to vote a certain way due to your circumstances. Unmarried and childless? Enjoy being a child yourself while the rest of us make adult decisions about the future.

Voting should NOT be given to everyone. You and your spouse should have to pass a test to earn the privilege to vote after you qualify. And if you skip voting one year, your family should lose your privileges until you or your spouse take a standardized test to prove your knowledge about how our country runs. Something like what immigrants take on moving here that could be passed by a high school student.
